lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component ToDoList that takes a list of ToDoItem components as children and displays them.

Make sure to pick <ToDoList> followed by <ToDoItem and then task="Learn React" />, <ToDoItem task="Build an App" />, </ToDoList>.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can children props enhance the flexibility of a React component?

By allowing the parent component to pass either simple text, plain HTML, or other componentsBy ensuring the component operates without any propsBy letting the component manage its state automaticallyBy guaranteeing no need for lifecycle methods

By allowing the parent component to pass either simple text, plain HTML, or other components.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a setup where a child component sends a timestamp to the parent component whenever you click a button.

Make sure to pick ( followed by ) and then props, .onTimeUpdate.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a simple React setup where a child component increases a counter located in the parent component each time a button is clicked.

Make sure to pick incrementCounter, followed by onIncrement, and finally incrementCounter.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Forward props to multiple components. Pass a pet's name to components A and B.

Make sure to pick { followed by petName and then }, pet=, {, petName, }, pet=, {, petName, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Transform received props. Have the Child component rename the prop role to job before passing it to Department.

Make sure to pick job, followed by role.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a reusable Notification component that accepts children to display varied types of messages.

Make sure to pick { followed by children and then }, children.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following describes how you can nest multiple React components within a parent component using the children prop?

It's similar to nesting HTML elements, where children are placed between the opening and closing tagsBy using a separate props object for each child componentBy importing each child component directly into the parent without any JSX contextBy applying CSS display properties to the parent component

It's similar to nesting HTML elements, where children are placed between the opening and closing tags.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
If a parent component wants to pass down a method to change its state, what is the correct way to proceed in React?

Define the method in the parent and pass it down as a prop to the childDefine the method in the child and then call it from the parentDefine the method in a sibling component and use it directlyMethods cannot change parent state when passed down to child components

Define the method in the parent and pass it down as a prop to the child.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a chain of components to modify and display the prop nickname as uppercase in FinalDisplay.

Make sure to type nickname.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the following component VehicleDisplay, how does modifying a prop affect the output?

The output speed will be shown as 120 km/hThe output speed remains at the initially passed value of 100 km/hThe output speed will be shown as 80 km/hNo output will be shown

The output speed will be shown as 120 km/h.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a MealCard component that accepts and modifies the dish prop before passing it to a child component.

Make sure to type props.dish.
